newsitem.title: USA: Chip stocks rise after book-to-bill report.
newsitem.headline: Chip stocks rise after book-to-bill report.

text.p: Stocks of computer chip makers rallied Wednesday after the industry reported that a key gauge of demand for memory chips rose to the highest level of the year in September.

The Semiconductor Industry Association reported Tuesday that its book-to-bill ratio rose to 0.99 in September from 0.93 in August. The reading means chip manufacturers received $99 in new orders last month for every $100 in shipments.
The rise reflected a stronger-than-expected increase in new orders, which rose to $3.19 billion, up 9 percent from August. Shipments inched up to $3.22 billion, 2.1 percent above August's level.
The ratio, considered a key indicator of the industry's direction, has been improving, reflecting better demand from personal computer makers and more stable prices for memory chips.
"People are buying PCs as if there's no tomorrow," analyst Dan Klesken at Robertson Stephens said after the report was issued. "We're having a PC-led recovery in the chip industry."
The stocks of some chip makers jumped in after-hours trading on Tuesday, and some managed solid gains Wednesday despite weakness in other high-technology issues as well as the broader market.

Texas Instruments jumped $1.125 to $56.25 and National Semiconductor added 50 cents to $20.375, both on the New York Stock Exchange. Applied Materials, which makes fabrication equipment for chip producers, rose $1 to $29 on Nasdaq.
Prices of memory chips tumbled over the year to a fraction of what they were in January. But since mid-September, memory prices have risen 30 percent to 50 percent from their lows.
The September ratio marked the highest level since December of 1995, when the index hit 1.12. A year ago it stood at 1.16.
Micron Technology Inc., a key chip maker, said last week that its excessive inventories of memory chips had fallen to desirable levels.
Micron shares were up 25 cents at $32.375, also on the NYSE.
